text.p: ** BIRTHDAYS **
The American poet who wrote "Hiawatha", HENRY WADSWORTH LONGFELLOW, was born on this day in 1807.
Englishman WILLIAM NICHOLSON, who established himself as a merchant in Victoria and became known as the "Father of the secret ballot" in the Victorian Parliament, was born in 1816.
JOHN BOOTH, the English-Australian pioneer shipbuilder who became the first Mayor of Balmain in New South Wales, was born in 1822.
Pulitzer-Prize winning American author JOHN STEINBECK ("The Grapes of Wrath", "East of Eden"), was born in 1902.
American actress JOANNE WOODWARD, who won an Oscar for "The Three Faces Of Eve", was born in 1930.
English-born Hollywood star ELIZABETH TAYLOR was born on this day in 1932.
Australian Rules Footballer and Coach RON BARASSI was born in 1936.
British guitarist with 'Iron Maiden' ADRIAN SMITH was born in 1957.
** EVENTS **
1782 : The British Parliament voted to abandon the
American War of Independence.
1788 : THOMAS BARRETT, a convicted thief, became the
first person sentenced to death in New South Wales.
1881 : The Boers defeated the British at the Battle of
Majuba Hill, South Africa. On the same day in 1900, the Boers were defeated by Lord Kitchener's men at the Battle of Paardenberg.
1900 : The British Labour Party was founded with Ramsay
MacDonald as its Secretary.
1902 : Two Australian officers were executed in South

Africa. Lieutenants HARRY HARBORD 'BREAKER' MORANT and PETER JOSEPH HANDCOCK were shot by firing squad after they were sentenced to death by a British High Command court for having shot a Boer prisoner. Another officer GEORGE WITTON was given a life sentence. MORANT was a well-known Sydney writer who wrote under the nom de plume "The Breaker". He was reputed to be an excellent horseman. HANDCOCK was a veterinary surgeon from

Western Australia. The execution order was controversial and at the time it was believed that their actions were understandable due to the fact that the Boers had been responsible for atrocities. Community opinion prompted WITTON's early release.
1933 : The German parliament building, the Reichstag, was
destroyed by fire. The Nazis claimed it was a Communist conspiracy and used it as an opportunity to clamp down on its opponents.
1942 : In the first phase of the Battle of Java Sea, three
Allied destroyers and a cruiser were sunk by the Japanese.
1948 : The Czechoslovakian Communist Party seized power
in Prague.
1952 : The United Nations sat for its first session in
New York.
1968 : The first Aborigine to win a world boxing title

defeated Japan's MASHIKO HARADA to win the bantamweight championship. The 20-year-old LIONEL ROSE from Drouin in Victoria fought in Tokyo, before a world television audience of around 30 million. ROSE knocked HARADA down in the ninth round. Returning to Australia ROSE was given a civic reception in Melbourne. The fighter lost his title in 1969 to Mexican RUBIN OLIVARES on a fifth-round knock out.
1977 : The popular Swedish group Abba arrived in Sydney
for an Australian tour.
1980 : American pop star MICHAEL JACKSON was awarded his
first "Grammy".
1986 : FERDINAND MARCOS fled the Philippines, for exile
in Hawaii.
1991 : United States President GEORGE BUSH ordered a halt
to Allied offensive action against Iraq, signalling an end to the Persian Gulf War.
1996 : U.N. sanctions against the Bosnian Serbs were
suspended following their compliance with conditions laid down by the Security Council.
